etymology.description: semantic: 肉 (“meat”) + phonetic: 匈 (OC *qʰoŋ); 匈 is the original form, with 肉 added later.
etymology.interpretation: Meat/flesh (肉) signals a body-part meaning, while 匈 provides the sound xiōng. Historically, 匈 was used alone, and adding 肉 clarified that the sense specifically relates to the chest as part of the body.

examples.chinese: 他捂着胸口(他捂著胸口)，疼得直不起腰(疼得直不起腰)。
examples.pinyin: Tā wǔ zhe xiōngkǒu, téng de zhí bù qǐ yāo.
examples.english: He clutched his chest and was in so much pain he couldn’t straighten up.

examples.chinese: 医生听他的胸部(醫生聽他的胸部)，说没有问题(說沒有問題)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng tīng tā de xiōngbù, shuō méiyǒu wèntí.
examples.english: The doctor listened to his chest and said there was no problem.

examples.chinese: 她胸怀宽广(她胸懷寬廣)，总能理解别人(總能理解別人)。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiōnghuái kuānguǎng, zǒng néng lǐjiě biérén.
examples.english: She is broad-minded and can always understand others.
